question: What season occurs in the Northern Hemisphere when it is tilted toward the Sun?

content.source_1: On or around the June solstice (around June 21), the Northern Hemisphere is tilted maximally toward the Sun.
content.source_2: The hemisphere tilted toward the Sun experiences summer because its days are longer and sunlight arrives more directly.
content.source_3: Earth reaches perihelion—its closest approach to the Sun—around early January, which falls during Northern Hemisphere winter.
content.source_4: Because Earth is closer to the Sun at perihelion, the solar energy arriving at the top of Earth’s atmosphere is about 6–7% higher than at aphelion.
content.source_5: Early January is typically among the coldest periods across much of the Northern Hemisphere, characteristic of winter conditions.
content.source_6: Due to seasonal lag from land and ocean heat capacity, Northern Hemisphere temperatures usually peak in July–August, several weeks after the June solstice.
